causes: Religious revolt led by Muhammad Ahmad, who proclaimed himself the Mahdi (the prophesied redeemer of Islam).
Desire to establish an independent Sudan free from Egyptian and British rule.
Grievances over Egyptian taxation, corruption, and oppression of the Sudanese people.
events_leading_up_to_war: In 1881, Muhammad Ahmad declared himself the Mahdi and started a religious and military campaign against the ruling forces in Sudan.
The Mahdist forces began gathering followers from the Sudanese tribes, quickly gaining momentum.

result.territorial_changes: Sudan became an independent state under the rule of the Mahdi, although it was later reconquered by British forces.

allies: Local Sudanese elites loyal to the Khedive

Mahdist_Army: Abdallahi ibn Muhammad (successor after Mahdi’s death)
Egyptian_Khedive: General Charles Gordon (British officer leading Egyptian forces)

Mahdist_Army.weapons: Spears, swords, muskets (some captured from the Egyptians)

major_battles.name: Battle of El Obeid
major_battles.description: A pivotal battle in which Mahdist forces decisively defeated Egyptian and British troops, securing the region of Kordofan.
major_battles.outcome: Mahdist victory, solidifying their control over much of Sudan.

major_battles.name: Siege of Khartoum
major_battles.description: A famous siege where Mahdist forces surrounded the British-led Egyptian garrison, eventually leading to the fall of Khartoum and the death of General Charles Gordon.
major_battles.outcome: Mahdist victory, marking the high point of their power in Sudan.

texts.name: The Mahdi’s Proclamation
texts.details: Document outlining Muhammad Ahmad's claim to be the Mahdi and his vision for an independent Sudan.

texts.name: British Military Reports
texts.details: Official reports documenting the British and Egyptian military response to the Mahdist threat.

archaeological_evidence.description: Artifacts, including captured Egyptian arms, Mahdist blades, and muskets, are found throughout Sudan and surrounding regions.
Remnants from the Siege of Khartoum and other key battles, including British artillery and Mahdist fortifications.

political: The Mahdist State controlled Sudan for several years, with Muhammad Ahmad’s successor, Abdallahi ibn Muhammad, becoming the new ruler.
The Mahdist State was eventually overthrown in 1898 by a British-Egyptian military campaign led by General Herbert Kitchener.
economic: Sudan fell into instability after the Mahdist victory but was later economically disrupted by British colonial rule.
long_term_effects: The Mahdist War shaped Sudan’s political landscape, marking a significant phase of resistance to imperial forces.
The conflict contributed to British domination of Sudan, which remained under British-Egyptian rule until 1956.

military: The Mahdist War marked a major indigenous resistance against European imperialism in Africa, showcasing the ability of local forces to resist advanced military powers.
political: It temporarily disrupted the influence of the Egyptian Khedive and the British Empire in the region, highlighting the potential for indigenous political movements to alter the balance of power.
cultural: The Mahdist War left a legacy in Sudanese history, where the figure of the Mahdi remains a central symbol of Sudanese independence and resistance.
